PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The Government of the Republic of the Union of Myanmar has requested the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  a  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  prepare  the 
Mandalay City Urban Services Improvement Project suitable for ADB financing. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The project preparatory TA will (i) conduct sector and subsector analysis; (ii) help prioritize and 
identify project components for the ensuing loan project; (iii) determine the feasibility of the proposed 
investments for priority infrastructure construction and improvements, and (iv) prepare an institutional 
capacity strengthening and public awareness programs. Climate change resilient designs will be 
introduced  in  infrastructure  construction  and  upgrading.  The  TA  will  also  prepare  the  project 
administration  manual  (PAM)  that  includes  all  the  information  and  schedules  describing  project 
implementation. The major outputs and activities of the TA are summarized in Table A4.1.

C.  Cost Estimates and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000 equivalent of which $1,000,000 will be financed 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others), $500,000 by the Multi-Donor Trust 
Fund1  under  the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  (WFPF),  and  $500,000  by  the 
Government of France through the Agence Française de Développement.2 All funds will be 
provided on a grant basis and administered by ADB. The funds from WFPF will be disbursed on 
a front loaded basis. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, office accommodation with furniture, communication facilities for consultants, relevant 
data, maps, and reports, and logistic assistance for the workshops and seminars. The detailed 
cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  A team of consultants will be engaged through firm(s). The TA will require 10 positions 
and 42 person-months (pm) of international, and 15 positions and 80 pm of national consulting 
services. ADB will select and engage consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Use 
of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The quality- and cost-based selection 
method with quality-cost ratio of 90:10, using full technical proposal procedures, will be followed. 
A small number of individual international and national consultants will be additionally engaged 
after submission of the draft final report, to support start-up activities of the ensuing loan project 
on an as-needed basis using the contingencies.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the consultants are described in Table A4.4 
 
Table A4.4: Outline Terms of Reference 
Sector and subsector analysis. The consultant will (i) review the existing urban development plans for 
Mandalay, and other relevant plans, regulations, reports, standards, and studies; (ii) assess climate 
change impacts; (iii) predict the future development needs and trends; and (iv) assess the existing 
institutional framework for urban planning, development, and management. 
Technical aspects. The consultant will (i) review subsector development plans, natural environment, 
existing infrastructure conditions, and institutional framework; (ii) consult key stakeholders to identify 
major issues and bottlenecks; (iii) prepare long-term development plans for water supply, drainage and 
flood control, and wastewater including septage management (iv) confirm the priority areas and finalize the 
infrastructure investment subprojects; (v) collect and analyze information on infrastructure and civil works;

Appendix 4             4   
(vi) analyze design alternatives and prepare conceptual engineering designs; (vii) introduce climate resilient 
designs for infrastructure facilities; (viii) prepare preliminary engineering design and cost estimates; (ix) 
prepare an operation and maintenance plan; (x) conduct the procurement capacity assessment; (xi) 
review the country procurement system and SOE eligibilities; (xii) prepare a procurement plan; and (xiii) 
prepare the PAM. 
Economic analysis. The consultant will (i) conduct socioeconomic surveys and prepare baseline data; 
(ii) conduct SWOT analysis; (iii) refine the project rationale; and (iv) prepare economic analyses for 
individual project components as well as the project as a whole following ADB’s guidelines. 
Financial analysis. The consultant will (i) conduct financial management assessments and recommend 
measures to strengthen financial management capacities; (ii) prepare detailed cost estimates and a 
project financing plan by financier, and design the funds flow and disbursement mechanism; (iii) propose 
auditor arrangements; (iv) establish cost recovery tariffs and connection charges; (v) prepare financial 
analyses  for  water  supply  and  wastewater  management  subprojects;  (vi)  forecast  the  incremental 
recurrent costs to ascertain the long-term impact of the project; (vii) address and propose a business 
model  for  the  components  which  have  the  potential  to  be  revenue-generating;  and  (viii)  conduct 
affordability assessment including willingness to pay. 
Environment. The consultant will (i) collect data on environmental conditions; (ii) conduct environment 
screening and assess the environment category of the project; (iii) assess the projected impacts of 
climate change on the project areas; (iv) assess the environmental impacts of the infrastructure works; (v) 
ensure close integration of environment sustainability and climate resilient in infrastructure designs; (vi) 
conduct an environment compliance audit for existing facilities which will be rehabilitated under the 
project; and (vii) prepare an initial environmental examination or environmental impact assessment for 
each subproject in accordance with ADB’s safeguard policy statement. 
Social safeguard. The consultant will (i) assess the significance of the land acquisition and resettlement 
impacts, and prepare resettlement plans accordingly per subproject in accordance with ADB’s safeguard 
policy statement; (ii) assess potential impacts on indigenous peoples and prepare documentation as 
required per subproject in accordance with ADB’s safeguard policy statement; (iii) help the government 
initiate a participatory process for RP preparation; (iv) conduct public consultations; and (v) assess the 
capacity  of  the  responsible  institutions  to  plan,  update,  and  implement  RPs,  and  propose  training 
programs. 
Institutional analysis and capacity strengthening. The consultant will (i) identify policy, institutional, 
regulatory, and human resource bottlenecks for urban planning and management, and municipal service 
delivery; (ii) assess the managerial, technical, financial, and administrative capacities; (iii) prepare realistic 
project implementation arrangements; (iv) review existing training programs; (v) prepare an institutional 
analyses; and (vi) develop capacity development programs for local government agencies. 
Social analysis. The consultant will (i) help conduct socioeconomic surveys; (ii) review the government 
policies and strategies for poverty reduction and gender development; (iii) conduct a public perception 
survey to identify public problems and development priorities; (iv) conduct a poverty and social analysis, 
(v) prepare a poverty reduction and social strategy; (vi) collect sex-disaggregated data for possible 
gender targets used in the project; (vii) develop gender targets in the design and monitoring framework; 
(viii) prepare a gender action plan; (ix) prepare a participation plan; (x) conduct a stakeholder analysis 
and prepare a stakeholder communication strategy; and (xi) develop public health and environmental 
protection awareness programs. 
Others. The consultant will administer the workshops, training, seminars and conferences, and surveys. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, EIA = environmental impact assessment, IEE = initial environmental examination, 
PAM = project administration manual; RP = resettlement plan, SOE = state-owned enterprise, SWOT = strengths, 
weakness, opportunities, and threats. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  The executing agency will be the Mandalay Regional Government and the implementing 
agency will be the Mandalay City Development Committee (MCDC).The Department of Human 
Settlements and Housing Development (DHSHD), Ministry of Construction (MOC) will provide 
overall guidance and support for the TA implementation. A project management unit will be

Appendix 4           5            
 
established under the MCDC to undertake day-to-day TA activities. Disbursements under the 
TA will be done in accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(May 2010, amended from time to time). The consultants may procure equipment through 
shopping in accordance with the ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, amended from time to 
time). Upon completion of the TA, equipment procured under the TA will be transferred to the 
executing agencies. The TA is expected to start on 1 January 2014 and completed by 30 June 
2015.
